message.name: A25
message.say: ! You have helped Jordan so much I can already tell.

message.name: A26
message.say: Try to remember the strategies we used in this lesson when you read from now on.

message.name: A27
message.say: Remember the article about cashing a check was an informational text, it provided you with facts such as how to endorse a check.

message.name: A28
message.say: The Williford bank ad was persuasive. The bank is trying to convince Jordan that he should cash his check there. The bank uses opinions to convince. Remember that opinions are not facts, they can be argued against.

message.name: A29
message.say: Goodbye Jordan and

message.name: A30
message.say: ! You two have a great day and try to do another lesson soon!

message.name: A31
message.say: Hi

message.name: A32
message.say: and Jordan! How are you two today!

message.name: A33
message.say: Don't worry Jordan,

message.name: A34
message.say: and I are here to help you. I found three different articles about cashing checks and paying bills that may help!

message.name: A35
message.say: I found a persuasive article, an informational article, and a narrative article.

message.name: A36
message.say: Persuasive articles use opinions to try and convince the reader of some point of view. An informational article contains many facts and is meant to inform the reader. A narrative text tells a story and entertains us by affecting our emotions.

message.name: A37
message.say: You got it! Let's take a look at the first article

message.name: A38
message.say: Read the article below and then we will talk about it. Click the blue continue button when you are done reading. Remember to use the read text button if you need help.

message.name: A39
message.say: , based on what we read, do you think this article is informational, persuasive, or narrative?

message.name: A40
message.say: This is an informational text because the writer uses facts to inform us about how to cash a check.

message.name: A41
message.say: Remember that facts, opinions, and emotion triggers inform us about the type of text. So does this text have a lot of facts, opinions or emotion triggers

message.name: A42
message.say: ? Think about it and then try a different answer choice.

message.name: A43
message.say: This is an informational text because the writer uses facts to to inform us about how to cash a check.

message.name: A44
message.say: Do you know the answer Jordan?

message.name: A45
message.say: So

message.name: A46
message.say: , what could happen to you or Jordan if you accept a check from someone you don't know?

message.name: A47
message.say: If Jordan accepts a check from someone he doesn't know the check could bounce.

message.name: A48
message.say: in the first section it says you should trust the person who wrote the check. What else does it say can happen if you don't trust the check writer?

message.name: A49
message.say: If you accept a check from a person who is not trustworthy, the check could bounce. Make sure you trust the person who writes you a check.

message.name: A50
message.say: Jordan which answer did you select?

message.name: A51
message.say: The bank has to verify that Jordans ID matches the name on the check before they can cash it! You have selected the correct answer.

message.name: A52
message.say: if Jordan doesn't have his ID he can't cash his check, but why? Why does he need to have his ID when he goes to cash his check

message.name: A53
message.say: Jordan has to bring his ID to the bank to prove to them he is who he says he is. The bank has to verify Jordan's identity before they can cash his check!

message.name: A54
message.say: Jordan what do you think the answer is to the question?

message.name: A55
message.say: , I have highlighted this sentence in the article for you! Does this sentence contain an opinion, a fact, or an emotion trigger?

message.name: A56
message.say: A fact states something that cannot be denied. In this case the fact is, to endorse a check you always have to flip it over and sign next to the x. Great job recognizing this is a fact

message.name: A58
message.say: This sentence contains a fact. The sentence states information that can not be argued against. The fact here was, In order to endorse a check you always have to flip it over and sign next to the x.

message.name: A59
message.say: What do you think the answer is Jordan?

message.name: A60
message.say: Jordan and

message.name: A61
message.say: here is a bank advertisement! Jordan may be able to cash his check at the Williford Bank! Let's take a look at the ad.

message.name: A62
message.say: click the continue button at the bottom of the page once you are finished reading.

message.name: A63
message.say: do you think this ad is mainly informational, persuasive, or narrative?

message.name: A64
message.say: The Williford Bank is trying to convince Jordan to use their banking services with this persuasive ad! You were correct!

message.name: A65
message.say: , ads are usually trying to convince us of something. Which type of text tries to convince us, informational, persuasive, or narrative texts?

message.name: A66
message.say: This is a persuasive ad. The Williford Bank is trying to convince Jordan to cash his check at their bank!

message.name: A67
message.say: What do you think the answer is Jordan?

message.name: A68
message.say: which of the highlighted phrases do you think is trying to convince Jordan?

message.name: A69
message.say: The phrase "we have the most helpful tellers" is a convincing statement, and not a fact or emotion trigger. Great answer

message.name: A70
message.say: , which highlighted statement is trying to convince us that Williford is the number one bank in the country?

message.name: A71
message.say: The Williford bank claims to have the most helpful bank tellers. That is one reason why they think they are the number one bank in the country! The ad is trying to convince us of that.

message.name: A72
message.say: What do you think the answer is Jordan?

message.name: A73
message.say: Some people will think the opinion that they have the most helpful bank tellers is true, while others might not agree. An opinion is not a fact, which means it has not been proven. You picked the correct answer.

message.name: A74
message.say: remember that an opinion is different from a fact because a fact is proven information. So how can we know that Williford banks claim is an opinion?

message.name: A75
message.say: An opinion is something that can be argued. Some people will think it is true while others will think it is not true. Also, an opinion is not a fact, which means it has not shown to be true.

message.name: A76
message.say: Jordan what do you think the answer is?

message.name: A77
message.say: and Jordan

message.name: A78
message.say: This passage is about a woman who had a bad experience when paying a bill! I think you may find this interesting so take a look!

message.name: A79
message.say: remember to click the continue button at the bottom of the page once you have finished reading.

message.name: A80
message.say: , do you think this text is informational, persuasive, or narrative?

message.name: A81
message.say: The passage tells us a story of how Anne pays her bills with the checks she cashes from her job. When a writer tells a story it is a narrative text. I hope you can both learn something from Anne's mistake! Great job

message.name: A82
message.say: since we read a passage that describes an experience, or story from Anne herself, that makes this article a what? A narrative, informational, or persuasive text?

message.name: A83
message.say: The passage tells us a story of how Anne pays her bills with the checks she cashes from her job. When a writer tells a story it is a narrative text. I hope you can both learn something from Anne's mistake!

message.name: A84
message.say: What do you think the answer is Jordan?

message.name: A85
message.say: Jordan could go to a money service center in a grocery store like Anne did in the story. This might be a good place for him to try to cash his check.

message.name: A86
message.say: Anne states that the place she goes to is authorized to take bill payments. What is the name of this location? Jordan may also be able to cash his check there.

message.name: A87
message.say: Jordan could go to a money service center in a grocery store like Anne did in the story. This might be a good place for him to try to cash his check.

message.name: A88
message.say: Jordan what do you think the answer is to the question?

message.name: A89
message.say: If Jordan goes to a place that is not authorized to take bill payments someone may steal his money. If you aren't sure whether you can pay your bills at a service location, ask the store manager or someone with authority.

message.name: A90
message.say: in the article Anne tells us that if the service is not authorized to take payments something bad may happen. What could happen if Jordan goes to a place that is not authorized to take bill payments?

message.name: A91
message.say: If Jordan goes to a place that is not authorized to take bill payments someone may steal his money. If you aren't sure whether you can pay your bills at a service location, ask the store manager or someone with authority.

message.name: A92
message.say: What do you think the answer is to the question Jordan?

message.name: A93
message.say: Anne tells us to make sure we do not make the same mistake she did! She sounds so passionate about it and even used an exclamation mark, so this was definitely an emotion trigger. Great job!

message.name: A94
message.say: remember that this article is a narrative. And narrative texts contain what type of information? Emotion triggers, facts, or opinions?

message.name: A95
message.say: Anne tells us to make sure we do not make the same mistake she did! She sounds so passionate about it and even used an exclamation mark, so this was definitely an emotion trigger.

message.name: A96
message.say: What do you think the answer is Jordan?
